title: Rumeysa Ozturk visa or green card revocation (Department of State)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any records concerning the revocation of a visa or green card with respect to Rumeysa Ozturk who was arrested on or about March 25, 2025.

2. Any communications with the White House concerning Rumeysa Ozturk.

3. Any communications with the Department of Homeland Security concerning Rumeysa Ozturk on or after January 20, 2025.

"Communications" means and includes emails, text messages, social media messages, letters, memoranda, calendar entries, chats, or any other form of one-to-one or one-to-many communication.

Please note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. For example, if an employee uses a personal cell phone or social media account to conduct public business, records created, maintained, or held on the phone or account are public records subject to this request.

REQUEST FOR EXPEDITED PROCESSING:

I request that this request be expedited under 22 CFR § 171.12(d)(1)(ii) for the following reasons:

1. I certify the following to be true and correct: My organization is primarily engaged in disseminating information. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE) maintains a news website at https://thefire.org/news, through which its staff members regularly publish news stories and editorial content concerning the activities of governments, government officials, and other persons or organizations of public concern. I am a staff member of FIRE. I frequently write about matters involving the First Amendment and free expression, including on FIRE's website. See, e.g., https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303. A substantial component of my duties as a staff member of FIRE is to obtain information through public records requests, including through the Freedom of Information Act, which I or my colleagues then share through FIRE's website and social media channels. I also publish news and other information of public concern via "X" (https://x.com/adamsteinbaugh) and "Bluesky" (https://bsky.app/profile/adamsteinbaugh.bsky.social).

2. The requested information concerns an actual or alleged government activity, namely the Department's involvement in the revocation of a visa or green card due to protest activity or expression protected by the First Amendment.

3. The requested information extends beyond the public's right to know about government activity generally and instead has a particular value that would be lost if not processed on an expedited basis. The information pertains to a news story of public interest. That issue has attracted a wide range of news media coverage, including the numerous articles identified below, which are helpful in establishing that there is an urgency to inform the public on this topic.

Examples of recent articles and statements demonstrating the public's ongoing and current interest in this information include:

a. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/26/us/ice-tufts-student-detained-rumeysa-ozturk.html
b. https://www.wsj.com/us-news/law/tufts-graduate-student-detained-by-federal-immigration-authorities-42d57a0a
c. https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-14540283/turkish-student-hijab-filmed-detained-ice-ramadan-tufts-university.html
d. https://www.smh.com.au/world/north-america/looked-like-a-kidnapping-uni-student-taken-by-masked-agents-in-trump-crackdown-20250327-p5lmy9.html
e. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/mar/26/ice-agents-detain-tufts-university-graduate-student
f. https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/tufts-student-detained-masked-federal-agents-1235304299/
g. https://www.bostonglobe.com/2025/03/26/metro/its-really-scary-students-residents-react-sudden-arrest-tufts-student/
h. https://www.axios.com/local/boston/2025/03/26/tufts-rumeysa-ozturk-detained
i. https://www.cnn.com/2025/03/26/us/video/tufts-student-detained-rumeysa-ozturk-ice-digvid
j. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2025/03/26/federal-agents-detain-tufts-university-student-turkey/82674919007/
k. https://www.boston25news.com/news/local/international-student-tufts-university-reportedly-taken-into-federal-custody/2VK55QMAOZFIDBR2A6XNKC5XOU/
l. https://www.boston.com/news/politics/2025/03/26/ag-campbell-says-shes-monitoring-situation-after-tufts-grad-student-arrested-by-ice/
m. https://www.bostonglobe.com/2025/03/26/metro/tufts-student-detailed-by-immigration-officials/
n. https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/100000010075008/tufts-student-ice-arrest.html?playlistId=video/latest-video
o. https://www.jns.org/common-sense-arrest-of-pro-hamas-protester-rumeysa-ozturk-says-homeland-security/
p. https://www.bostonherald.com/2025/03/26/tufts-graduate-student-whos-pro-palestinian-detained-by-federal-authorities-in-somerville/
q. https://www.rawstory.com/watch-stunning-video-shows-turkish-tufts-grad-student-cuffed-by-homeland-security/
r. https://forward.com/fast-forward/707596/tufts-international-grad-student-detained-by-ice-in-latest-action-targeting-pro-palestinian-activist/
s. https://www.mediaite.com/news/disturbing-video-shows-masked-men-hauling-away-pro-palestine-student-her-whereabouts-are-unknown/
t. https://www.huffpost.com/entry/rumeysa-ozturk-canary-mission-tuft-university_n_67e44604e4b00db00a39340e
u. https://www.foxnews.com/video/6370602253112
v. https://www.reuters.com/world/us/tufts-says-international-student-taken-into-us-custody-visa-revoked-2025-03-26/
w. https://nypost.com/2025/03/26/us-news/tufts-says-international-student-taken-into-us-custody-visa-revoked/
x. https://pressley.house.gov/2025/03/26/rep-pressleys-statement-on-arrest-of-tufts-student-rumeysa-ozturk/
y. https://www.nbcnews.com/now/video/video-shows-arrest-of-tufts-university-graduate-student-235439685766
z. https://www.cair.com/press_releases/cair-ma-condemns-ice-abduction-of-tufts-student-rumeysa-ozturk/
aa. https://www.seattletimes.com/news/turkish-student-at-tufts-university-detained-video-shows-masked-people-handcuffing-her/
bb. https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2025-03-26/turkish-student-at-tufts-university-detained-video-shows-masked-people-handcuffing-her


REQUEST FOR A FEE WAIVER OR REDUCED FEES:

I request, under 22 CFR § 171.16(j), a waiver or reduction of fees for the following reasons:

1. Disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because its disclosure would shed light on the operations or activities of the government. The requested information pertains specifically to controversial conduct by United States officials in response to campus protests.

2. Disclosure of the requested information would be likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations or activities. Disclosure of the requested information would meaningfully inform the public about the Department's activities and operations.

3. Disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons interested in the subject, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requester. The requestor is a licensed attorney who practices First Amendment law. As such, the requestor will be able to effectively convey information to the public. Further, the requestor is a representative of the news media. The requestor and his employer, the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, gather information of potential interest to a segment of the public, turns that information into distinct works (including through its news website, located at https://thefire.org/news), and distributes that information to the public. The information requested here relates to information that is about current events or that would be of current interest to the public. The requestor's past publication record (in addition to FIRE's articles available at https://thefire.org/news) is available at https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303.

4. The requested information is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. The requestor works for a nonprofit organization and the records are not sought for a commercial purpose.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Putnam County Opioid Settlement Fund Request

communications.subject: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Putnam County Opioid Settlement Fund Request
communications.communication:
Johnathan Edwards 
2040 University Avenue- Apartment 301
Morgantown, WV 26505

02/24/2025

Brian Wood
Putnam County Clerk
Clerk’s Office of Putnam County
12093 Winfield Road #3
Winfield, WV 25213

Dear Mr. Wood: 

Under the West Virginia Freedom of Information Act, §29-B-1-1 et seq., I am requesting an opportunity to inspect or obtain copies of public records that show the following; Allocation of opioid settlement funds received by Putnam County, the application that individuals or organizations seeking funding from the county complete, copies of grant applications from individuals or organizations that have been approved to receive these funds, the individuals who will review the funding applications, any meeting minutes of county-level officials where the receiving or distribution of county-level opioid settlement funding was discussed, and how much funding has been awarded as of March 1, 2025, and to whom it was awarded. If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $25. However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of how this large sum of allocated funds is being distributed across the county. I am a student reporter at West Virginia University and intend to use this information to more accurately report on these findings. This information is not being sought for commercial purposes. The West Virginia Freedom of Information Act requires a response to this request be made within five business days. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer than this amount of time, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records. You can call me at 304-638-6367 or send me an email at jde00006@mix.wvu.edu My physical address is 2040 University Ave. Morgantown, WV, 26505.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Documentation/certification of DOGE's "rigorous data standards."
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

As part of its establishing Executive Order (and cited in multiple Memorandums of Understanding between USDS and other agencies) is the line "USDS shall adhere to rigorous data protection standards." I would like to request any further documentation outlining how systems are certified to comply with these standards. These might include the following artifacts:

1. Formal compliance documentation like Authorizations to Operate (ATOs) or System Security Plans (SSPs) or "baselines" that outline the appropriate FISMA level for DOGE systems that collect data (Low/Moderate/High), what NIST controls they must demonstrate meeting and documentation of evidence they have met those NIST controls.
2. Guidance/internal documentation to DOGE staff about properly securing data both in transit and at rest. Considering that many of the DOGE staff are both new to federal employment and working with data from multiple agencies, does this include any mandatory training or signed rules of behavior, etc.
3. Any information on system configuration or automated tools that are used to ensure these rigorous data standards are being met on USDS equipment.
4. Any MOUs or agreements for transferring data between agencies and USDS that include more detailed requirements on how they should meet the requirements of this mandate.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jacob Harris

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: sUAS Operations (2024-2025)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Mission documentation of each sUAS deployment in 2024-2025 so far, sufficient to determine the date, time, location, and purpose of each deployment. Please see P135695-041424, a similar request, for reference.

If this is not available, an index with file name, date created, location (if available), length, and any other available metadata of video files created as a result of sUAS deployments in 2023.

2. Any available CAD data and dispatch communications regarding any incident in which KCSO deployed sUAS to assist Seattle PD/SPD SWAT in 2024/2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: overdose data
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any draft or preliminary data, internal reports, or summaries regarding non-fatal and fatal overdoses among Boston residents for calendar years 2023, 2024, and 2025 (to date), collected under the CDC Overdose Data to Action (OD2A) grant or from other sources. 
Any data files, internal communications, or documentation used for reporting or submitting this information to the CDC during the same period.
Any draft or pending updates to the Boston Overdose Dashboard, including materials related to updates in Microsoft Power BI, whether or not those updates have been published publicly.

As the current OD2A grant cycle runs from September 1, 2023, through August 31, 2028, and includes funding for enhanced surveillance and timely dissemination of data, responsive records for this period are expected to exist even if not yet finalized for publication.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brian McCarter

title: Clinton Sanitation Use of Laurens County Transfer Station

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the South Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any and all agreements, memorandums of understanding (MOUs), authorizations, or written permissions between the City of Clinton and Laurens County (or any of its departments) that authorize Clinton Sanitation to dispose of waste at the Laurens County Transfer Station (formerly the old Laurens landfill).

2. Weigh tickets, intake logs, daily reports, manifests, billing statements, or invoices documenting any waste received from the City of Clinton or its sanitation department, including waste routed to Twin Chimney landfill.

3. Internal emails, letters, or communications between Laurens County staff or officials and the City of Clinton (or its sanitation department) regarding trash disposal, dump site access, or waste transport arrangements.

4. Any records or documentation maintained by Laurens County Recycling and Collections Department that reference the City of Clinton’s use of county-operated waste facilities or routes used to deliver municipal waste.

This request follows a prior FOIA submission that was denied based on the claim that no responsive records exist. However, recent public statements from a sanitation worker have confirmed daily waste disposal operations by Clinton at the Laurens County Transfer Station, which is operated by the Laurens County Recycling and Collections Department. This indicates responsive documents do, in fact, exist.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Edwin Chadwick

communications.subject: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: 2009 Crime Incidents Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2009
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block

All public records request are handled on a first come first serve basis and responded to promptly once the records have been retrieved, reviewed, and redacted if necessary to prevent confidential or exempt information from being disclosed.  If there is a cost associated with your request, an estimate will be provided. Payment is due in order to begin processing the request when necessary. 
  
 Pursuant to Section §119.07(4)(d), F.S., if the nature or volume of the public records requested to be inspected, examined or copied is such as to require extensive use of information technology resources or extensive clerical or supervisory assistance by personnel, or both, a special service charge in addition to the actual cost of duplication will be assessed, except for law enforcement agencies.     
  
 If your request is too broad to identify any particular set of records, a representative may contact you to discuss if it can be revised to be more specific.  In addition, Florida’s public records law obligates agencies to provide copies of public records and does not obligate agencies to create records or answer questions.    
  
 Your understanding of this process is greatly appreciated.  If you require additional information, please contact the Office of the City Clerk at (305) 622-8000. 
  
 Thank you! 
  
 City of Miami Gardens 
  
 Office of the City Clerk 
  
 18605 NW 27th Avenue, Miami Gardens, FL 33056 
  
 Main: (305) 622-8000 | records@miamigardens-fl.gov 
  
 www.miamigardens-fl.gov

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: 2010, 2011 and 2015 Crime Incident Requests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2010, 2011 and 2015
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block

communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

All unedited body-worn camera / bodycam recordings related to the following law enforcement critical incident: 

Incident Date: May 19, 2023
Location: 1100 block of Park Avenue, Orange Park, FL
Victim Name: Zonchez Delarfette Prince-Holmes

I am specifically requesting the unedited body-worn camera recordings captured by all officers present for the full duration of the incident, including audio recordings associated with the footage.

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: ORT charges (San Bernardino County District Attorney)
communications.communication:
Mr. Scott,

The San Bernardino County District Attorney’s Office has received your California Public Records Act (CPRA) request.

The statistical information that you have requested is not contained in a preexisting document. It would require a District Attorney technician to perform a data harvest of the case management system. You would bear the cost of performing this work. (Gov. Code, § 7922.575.) We would provide an estimate and will require prepayment. The amount will likely be in the hundreds of dollars.

The information that can be provided as part of the data harvest is limited to that which is found in public records that are filed with the court; the District Attorney’s case management system is not itself a public record. It contains information that is exempt under the CPRA; the case management system is a local summary criminal history database (Gov. Code, § 7927.705; Pen. Code, § 13300), it contains investigatory file records (Gov. Code, § 7923.600), it contains attorney work product (Gov. Code, § 7927.705; Code Civ. Proc., § 2018.030), and it contains other privileged information (Gov. Code, § 7927.705; Evid. Code, § 1040).

A data harvest could produce the following:

Date range: 1/1/2019–3/11/2025
Charges searched for: Penal Code section 490.4, subdivision (a); Penal Code section 459.5; Penal Code section 484, subdivision (a); Penal Code section 490.2

For each case, the following data would be returned:


  *   DA case number
  *   Court case number
  *   Defendant name
  *   Defendant date of birth
  *   Date of offense
  *   Date of initial case filing
  *   All charges filed
  *   Disposition/outcome of each charge
  *   Sentence
  *   Sentence date

This data would be put in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet. Case numbers and defendant names would be used to keep the data organized.

In our system, the special allegation under Penal Code section 490.2 is structured like an offense, so we would search for it that way.

Using the defendant’s date of birth and the date of the offense, you will be able to determine the defendant’s age.

Our system does not track gender. It tracks sex, which is generally not systematically included on publicly filed records, and is therefore is not included in the proposed data harvest.

Race/national origin/ethnicity is not systematically included on publicly filed records and is therefore not included in the proposed data harvest. While it may be included incidentally, in some cases, it would be unduly burdensome to manually review each case to see if that occurred—such as if a motion was litigated where a defendant’s description was given. Separately, that description could have been incorrect.

We are uncertain what you mean by “amount of theft if entered in PIMS.” We would not be able to provide you with amount of theft information, as that amount is not tracked in our system.

Please review the proposed data harvest. If you are satisfied with it, we will forward it to our data analysts for an estimate of how long it will take and how much it will cost. It will most likely be hundreds of dollars.

Cordially,

Brent Schultze
Lead Deputy District Attorney
Appellate Services Unit
San Bernardino County District Attorney's Office
303 W. Third Street, Fifth Floor
San Bernardino, CA, 92415-0511

communications.subject: RE: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: Correspondence between Indiana State Police, Carroll County Sheriff’s Office, and Jeffrey Turco
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

Please allow this message to serve as confirmation that Purdue University has received your request for public records.  Your request will be processed in accordance with Indiana’s Access to Public Records Act (APRA).

Please note that the APRA does not require the production of documents within seven days. Rather, the APRA provides that the request will be deemed denied if the requester does not receive a response from the state agency within seven days.  This message serves as that response.

I will reach out to the department that maintains the record you are requesting.  Once a record is received and reviewed, I will provide you with a response.

Thank you,
Kaity

610 Purdue Mall

title: The Murders of Abby Williams and Libby German

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: The Murders of Abby Williams and Libby German
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request all reasonably segregable, non-exempt responsive documents associated with the investigation into the murders of Abigail “Abby” Williams and Liberty “Libby” German (UFCN: 7C-IP-2134732), including but not limited to the following: 

1. Electronic communications (FD-1057 forms)
2. Incident data and summaries
3. Investigation narratives and interview synopses (FD-302 forms)
4. Collected item and evidence entry logs (FD-1087 forms)
5. Tips, leads, investigative reports, and documents shared with the FBI by other law enforcement agencies and individuals (FD-1036, titled “Import Forms”)
6. Laboratory examination requests (FD-1121 forms)
7. Search warrant affidavits and applications
8. Signed search warrants
9. Search warrant execution logs
10. Property receipts (FD-597 forms)
11. Evidence collected item logs (FD-886 forms)
12. Photographic logs (FD-674 forms)
13. Presumptive test logs

Abby and Libby were found murdered near the Monon High Bridge in Delphi, Carroll County, Indiana, on February 14, 2017. On November 11, 2024, Richard Allen was convicted of these murders and sentenced to 130 years in prison. 

Relevant media releases can be found here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_mTpaRs-0n_oNGGezgkxsY6WD5WeRSvg

Court documents regarding the State of Indiana’s case against Richard M. Allen can be found here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/111qXoXAw9YJ_8b3KV0EsEIeiYmOHeuH1

Please note that Ronald E. Logan, who was investigated as a person of interest in 2017, passed away on January 24, 2022. As such, he no longer has personal privacy interests protected under the Privacy Act of 1974. See attached document titled “20220302_Ron_Logan_Public_Notice.pdf” for proof of death.

I would also like to request expedited processing of this request. The FBI may grant expedited processing when the request concerns a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest, which may raise questions about the government's integrity and affect public confidence (see 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(d)(iii), (iv) (2014)). 

For a significant portion of the interested public, the investigation and subsequent conviction of Richard Allen did not instill confidence. The government’s integrity is at stake. To increase transparency and restore public confidence, I intend to disseminate the requested records to a large audience in their original form, without restriction. 

If previously released records are available, I request a rolling release of those records while additional records are located and processed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Carl McGehee

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Banpop
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated during the course of the "Banpop" program, described in previously released records as a "code name for identification of Soviet illegals through fund transfers performed at Swiss banks".  A summary was provided in  a 1971 Domestic Intelligence Division inspection report: “BANPOP is the code name for a program initiated in August, 1966, in an attempt to identify illegals in the U. S. who may be receiving funds through Swiss banks. The basis for the program was an analysis of four Soviet illegal cases between 1955 and 1966 in which the Banque Populaire Swisse of Switzerland was used by the Soviets to fund illegals. The transfers are screened with the following criteria: (1) the person or individual beneficiary is named; (2) the amount of the transfer is between $300 and $5000 and (3) the last name of the person ordering and receiving is the same of of the money and is directed to a specific bank account.” (https://archive.org/details/FBI-Church-Committee-File/62-116395-441-475/page/4/mode/2up, https://archive.org/details/FBI-Church-Committee-File/62-116395-586-Bulky2/page/126/mode/2up) This is to include file 65-HQ-70741 and any associated bulky files, sub-files, and enclosures behind file.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. This is also to include any responsive records held in offsite locations, such as the Alexandria Records Center. Please include both investigatory and non-investigatory records in your search. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante
